{{coord|40.767417|-73.980321|display=title}} [[File:Gainsborough Studios 222 Central Park South.jpg|thumb|upright|400px|Gainsborough Studios, 2014]] '''Gainsborough Studios''' is a 1908 building located at 222 [[Central Park South]] in Manhattan, New York City. The 16-story building contains 34 artist's studios, each unit features double height, 18 foot ceilings with double height windows facing north and overlooking [[Central Park]]. A well-heeled artist rented each studio as working space, primarily producing oil portraits for well-heeled patrons.
The building was designed as a combination studio and living space for artists, featuring shared kitchen areas, a laundry, and a private dining room, as well as a reception area for clients.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Zimmer|first1=Lori|title=Gainsborough Studios|url=http://art-nerd.com/newyork/gainsborough-studios/|website=art-nerd.com|publisher=Art Nerd New York|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
The facade features a bust of the English painter [[Thomas Gainsborough]], a [[bas-relief]], or [[frieze]], ''Procession of the Arts'', by [[Isidore Konti]], and a tile mural by [[Henry Chapman Mercer]] and his [[Moravian Pottery and Tile Works]].<ref name="DolkartLandmarks">{{cite book|last1=Dolkart|first1=Andrew|title=Guide to New York City Landmarks|date=2008|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=0470289635|page=128}}</ref>
The architects were Herbert Harde and R. Thomas Short, originally named Herbert Spencer Steinhardt (born about 1873) and Richard Thomas Short (born about 1870), each had shortened his name. Together they formed the well-known New York architectural firm, [[Harde & Short]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Grey|first1=Christopher|title=2 Architects' Brief Journey Into Design Pyrotechnics|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/04/realestate/2-architects-brief-journey-into-design-pyrotechnics.html|accessdate=21 February 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2 December 2005}}</ref>
The building has been a designated [[New York City Landmark]] since 1988.<ref name="DolkartLandmarks" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Commons category-inline|Gainsborough Studios 222 Central Park South}}
[[Category:Apartment buildings in New York City]] [[Category:Residential buildings completed in 1908]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:Residential buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Landmarks in Manhattan]] [[Category:Artist colonies]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Spanish name 2|Leite|Gusinky}} '''Gustavo Alfredo Leite Gusinky''' is a [[Paraguay]]an businessman and politician.
==Biography== Leite studied Business Administration at the [[University of California, Irvine]] (Major in Finance, Minor in Economics) and also at the [[Chapman University]]; he obtained a Master in International Marketing at the Scottish Marketing School, [[University of Strathclyde]], in 1988.<ref name="hc">{{cite web |url=http://www.hcpresidente.com/articulo/1521-curriculum-de-los-ministros-del-gabinete-.html |title=CV of the ministers |date=12 August 2013 |publisher=HCPresidente.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814223433/http://www.hcpresidente.com/articulo/1521-curriculum-de-los-ministros-del-gabinete-.html |archivedate=14 August 2013 |df= }} {{es icon}}</ref>
Leite served as Planning Minister during the presidency of [[Raúl Cubas Grau]] (1998-1999).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanguardia.com.py/v1/index.php/component/k2/item/6224-los-hombres-de-cartes |title=The men of Cartes |date=27 June 2013 |publisher=Vanguardia.com.py |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130827054229/http://www.vanguardia.com.py/v1/index.php/component/k2/item/6224-los-hombres-de-cartes |archivedate=27 August 2013 |df= }} {{es icon}}</ref>
On 15 August 2013 he was sworn in as Minister of Industry and Commerce of Paraguay in the [[Cabinet of Paraguay|cabinet]] of President [[Horacio Cartes]].<ref name="jura">{{cite web |url=http://www.informador.com.mx/internacional/2013/478855/6/cartes-jura-a-los-11-ministros-de-su-gabinete.htm |title=Cartes' new ministers sworn in |accessdate=20 August 2013 |publisher=Informador.com.mx}} {{es icon}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Found the 1875 origin reason (from another magazine that merged with it); updating history accordingly.
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=June 2015}} {{COI|date=August 2010}} }} {{Infobox magazine |image_size = |image_file = |image_caption = |editor_title = Editor |editor = David Eisen |previous_editor = |staff_writer = |category = Hospitality industry, hotel management, magazine |frequency = 15x |circulation = |publisher = Amy Vaxman |founded = 1875 |company = Questex, LLC |country = USA |based = New York City |language = |website = [http://www.hotelmanagement.net/ ''Hotel Management''] |issn = 0018-6082 |oclc = 610525317 }} '''''Hotel Management''''' magazine is a [[Trade journal|trade publication]] produced by Questex, LLC.<ref>{{cite news|title=HotelWorld To Debut in Las Vegas September 18-20, 2007|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/hotelworld-to-debut-in-las-vegas-september-18-20-2007-56463207.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=PR Newswire|date=20 November 2006|location=Newton}}</ref>
==History and profile== The magazine ''Hotel Management'' was established in New York in 1922 by Ahrens Publishers. <ref>{{cite journal|title=Announcing a "Made-to-Measure" Magazine|journal=Hotel Management|date=February 1922|volume=1|issue=1|page=1|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.c2535285;view=1up;seq=9|accessdate=8 April 2018}}</ref> It absorbed or merged with various other hotel management magazines over the years, including ''Hotel World'', which had been established in 1875. The magazine sometimes took on other names such as ''Hotel & Motel Management''.<ref>{{cite book|author=Martin Scarrott|title=Sport, Leisure and Tourism Information Sources|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LHIABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA96|accessdate=25 April 2017|date=3 November 2009|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-36455-6|page=96}}</ref>, reflecting these mergers or changes in the market.
The magazine delivered hotel news, analysis and operational strategies. Regular features included special reports, research/top lists, hot products, technology, furniture, fixtures and equipment, hotel operations, and trends and statistics. Later owners included Advanstar Communications, Inc.<ref>{{cite web|title=All editions for 'Hotel & motel management'|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/hotel-motel-management/oclc/1681167/editions?referer=di&editionsView=true|work=WorldCat|accessdate=25 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Hadyn Ingram|title=Business of Hotels|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QC3cTxSAhCsC&pg=PA203|accessdate=25 April 2017|date=7 June 2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1-136-35944-3|page=203}}</ref>
In January 2011, the magazine was redesigned and renamed ''Hotel Management''.<ref name=fol>{{cite news|author=Jason Fell|title=Questex Renames, Redesigns Hotel & Motel Management|url=http://www.foliomag.com/questex-renames-redesigns-hotel-motel-management/|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=Folio:|date=12 October 2010}}</ref> Following these changes the magazine began to cover articles about [[technology]], development and trends/statistics.<ref name=fol/> It is published fifteen times a year.<ref name=fol/> It was formerly published 21 times per year.<ref name=trat>{{cite book|title=Travel and Tourism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SmMcHkpviiAC&pg=PT187|accessdate=25 April 2017|year=2010|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-8078-6|page=187}}</ref> Its headquarters is in [[New York City]].<ref name=trat/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.hotelworldnetwork.com/ HotelWorld Network]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hotel and Motel Management}} [[Category:American monthly magazines]] [[Category:American business magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1875]] [[Category:Magazines published in Ohio]] [[Category:Media in Cleveland]] [[Category:Magazines published in New York City]]
{{trade-mag-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2014}} [[Image:Khyberpassrifles.jpg|thumb|240px|Copies of British [[Martini–Henry|Martini]] and Snider firearms built in the Khyber region]] A '''Khyber Pass copy''' is a firearm manufactured by cottage gunsmiths in the [[Khyber Pass]] region between [[Pakistan]] and [[Afghanistan]].
The area has long had a reputation for producing unlicensed, homemade copies of firearms using whatever materials are available – more often than not, railway rails, scrap motor vehicles, and other [[Scrap|scrap metal]]. The quality of such firearms varies widely, ranging from as good as a factory-produced example to dangerously poor.
==Models== [[Image:Webleypocket.jpg|thumb|240px|Copy of Webley Pocket Pistol in .38 S&W, purchased at [[Bagram Airfield]], [[Afghanistan]]]] The most commonly encountered Khyber Pass copies are of British military firearms, notably [[Martini–Henry]], [[Martini–Enfield]], and [[Lee–Enfield]] rifles, although [[AK-47]] rifles, [[Webley Revolver]]s, [[Tokarev TT-33]]s, [[Colt M1911]]s and [[Browning Hi-Power]]s have also been encountered. In the United States, a Kalashnikov-style rifle composed of a mix of parts from various style AK rifles is sometimes referred to as a Khyber Pass AK because, like Khyber guns, they are unlike any rifle produced by a factory or issued by a regular military force. The typical example of a "Khyber Pass AK" is a stamped [[Receiver (firearms)|receiver]] AKM chambered for the [[7.62×39mm]] cartridge, fitted with the triangular folding stock common to Russian [[AK-74|AKS-74]] rifles.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
The Khyber Pass gunsmiths first acquired examples of the various British service arms during nineteenth-century British military expeditions in the [[North-West Frontier (military history)|North-West Frontier]], which they used to make copies. During [[World War II]], some locally organised [[Irregular military|irregular forces]] were issued Khyber Pass-made rifles – partly for financial reasons and partly because there was concern the troops would steal their rifles and desert if issued higher-quality British or Indian manufactured rifles.<ref>Ian Skennerton, ''The Lee-Enfield Story'' (1993). Arms & Militaria Press, Gold Coast QLD (Australia) {{ISBN|1-85367-138-X}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Identification== {{externalvideo|video1=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zTvxFNRLbiw Khyber Pass Martini Pistol at RIA]}} Khyber Pass rifles are usually copied exactly from a "master" rifle (which may itself be a Khyber Pass copy), markings and all. It's not uncommon to see Khyber Pass rifles with numerous errors and particular identifying factors, notably: *Spelling errors in the markings (the most common of which is EИFIELD for ENFIELD)<ref name="Atkin">{{cite web |url=http://www.martinihenry.com/khyberpage.html |title=The Khyber Pass Martini |author=Jason Atkin |publisher=[http://www.martinihenry.com/index.html Martini-Henry Rifles and Cartridges site] |accessdate=2009-07-01}}</ref><ref name="Manning2013">{{cite book|author=Stephen Manning|title=The Martini-Henry Rifle|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sesENlxA8QAC&pg=PT107|date=20 May 2013|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1-78096-508-6|pages=107–}}</ref> *V.R. (''Victoria Regina'') cyphers dated after 1901 – [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]] died in 1901, so any rifles made after this should be stamped "E.R" (''Edward Rex'', referring to [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|King Edward VII]]) *Generally inferior workmanship, including weak or soft metal, poorly finished wood, and badly struck markings.
Afghanistan was a [[The Great Game|point of conflict]] between the British Empire and Imperial Russia throughout the 19th century, from which it is reasonable to assume that tools and expertise relevant to both cultures were accumulated by native gunsmiths. Rather than a translation error, a reversed "N" or "L" in ENFIELD may be the [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] "И" and "Г" characters, with the gunsmith using whatever [[Punch (metalworking)|letter punches]] similar to original letters, but ensuring it can be identified as duplicate to avoid legal issues of using original trademark names.
==Ammunition== Not only are there counterfeit weapons, but there is counterfeit ammunition as well. Typically they are based on low-powered modern cartridges. .30 [[Gauge (firearms)|bore]] cartridges are compatible with [[7.63×25mm Mauser]] or [[7.62×25mm Tokarev]]. .32 bore cartridges are compatible with [[.32 ACP|.32 Auto Colt Pistol / 7.65mm Browning (7.65×17mmSR)]]. 12 bore cartridges are [[Gauge (bore diameter)#Sizes in use|12 gauge (18.5x70mmR)]] [[shotgun shell]]s.
44 bore cartridges are compatible with the [[7.92×33mm Kurz]] round for the World War Two era [[StG 44]]. Pakistan has a ban on rifles designed to fire military cartridges; the use of the 44 bore cartridge was a loophole in the law until specifically banned in 2012. It was used in AKM copies chambered or modified for it. It was a popular cartridge because it was easy to modify AKMs to fire it but still fed from standard AK magazines. Saquib brand makes 44 bore ammunition.
The ammunition used in the Khyber Pass region is often underloaded, being made from a variety of powders or even old film (which contains nitrocellulose, a key component of [[smokeless powder]]); Khyber Pass Copy rifles cannot be expected to withstand the pressures generated by modern commercial ammunition. A few collectors have made extremely mild handloaded cartridges for their Khyber Pass rifles and fired them, at substantial personal risk.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
The packaging and [[headstamp]]s are often forged versions of quality foreign brands like GECO (''Gustav Genschow & Co.''), Golden Tiger (Vympel [[Integrated reporting|IIRC]]), China Sport ([[NORINCO]]), MEN (''Metallwerk Elisenhütte Nassau''), and PPU ([[Prvi Partizan|Prvi Partizan Užice]]). Local counterfeits have colorful brand-name packaging like Buffalo, Diamond, Double Dragon, Double Star, Federal SKF, Goodluck, Gorilla, and Tiger SBR.
The Khyber Arms Company, a local ammunition manufacturer, makes the Expert or X-Pert brand. It uses counterfeit Winchester ammunition packaging with cartridges stamped with fake [[NORINCO]] ''State Factory 311'' headstamps.
New casings and bullet jackets are usually copper-washed steel, like Chinese ammunition. The casings are sometimes recycled from scrounged US or NATO military brass casings. 5.56mm NATO cases are cut-down and reshaped to make .30 bore rounds. [[9×19mm Parabellum]] cases are cut down to make reloaded [[.380 ACP|.380 ACP / 9×17mm Short]] or [[9×18mm Makarov]] rounds.
==See also== *[[Antique firearms]] *[[Arms industry]] *[[Artisan]] *[[Cottage industry]] *[[Counterfeit consumer goods]] *[[Gun culture in Pakistan]] *[[Gunsmith]] *[[Replica]] *[[Saturday night special]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *''Vice Magazine'', [https://www.vice.com/read/lets-v11n2 "Let's Go Pakistan!"]
[[Category:Firearms of Pakistan]] [[Category:Military industry]] [[Category:Replicas]] [[Category:Gun politics in Pakistan]] [[Category:Military history of British India]] [[Category:Military history of Pakistan]] [[Category:Military history of Afghanistan]]

page.title: Law of carriage of goods by sea

revision.text:
{{about|private shipping law|the law of maritime states |Law of the sea}}
The '''law of carriage of goods by sea''' is a body of law that governs the rights and duties of shippers, carriers and consignees of marine cargo.<ref>''The Law of Carriage of Goods by Sea'' (2011) - L.Singh</ref>
Primarily concerned with '''[[cargo claim]]s''', this body of law is an aspect of [[international commercial law]] and [[maritime law]].
==Cargo claims== {{Main|freight claim}} [[Consignee]]s (or indeed any lawful holder of the [[bill of lading]])<ref>Bill of lading, or sea way bill or ship's delivery order: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act 1992 ss.1 & 2</ref> who wishes to make a cargo claim because their goods are substandard or have been lost or damaged at sea, typically have four options: * They may sue the '''seller''', the '''shipper''', or the '''carrier'''; or they may claim from their own '''insurance policy'''. * A suit will lie against the seller if the seller has insufficient title,<ref> Sale of Goods Act1979 (as amended), section 12</ref> or the goods are not of satisfactory quality,<ref> Sale of Goods Act1979 (as amended), section 14</ref> or do not comply with sample<ref> Sale of Goods Act1979 (as amended), section 15</ref> or description.<ref> Sale of Goods Act1979 (as amended), section 13</ref> * A suit will lie against the shipper if the goods are damaged through insufficient packing,<ref>Hague Visby Rules Art. IV Rule 2(n)</ref><ref>''Goodwin v Lamport and Holt'' [1929] All ER 623</ref> or if any loss is suffered through insufficient labelling.<ref>Hague Visby Rules Art. III</ref><ref>''Parsons v New Zealand Shipping'' [1901] KB 548</ref><ref>''Bunge v Brasil'' [2009] 2 Lloyds Rep 175 </ref> * A suit will lie against the carrier if the damage occurred aboard ship.<ref>Hague-Visby Rules Arts. II & III</ref> The carrier's [[Protection and indemnity insurance|P&I Club]] cover will normally bear the cost. * If the cargo is damaged where the shipper without fault (e.g. if the goods have been properly packed and stowed) or if the carrier is either blameless or exempted from liability<ref>Hague-Visby Rules Art IV</ref> (e.g. because of '[[Act of God]]' or '[[Deviation (law) |Justifiable Deviation]]'), <ref>''The Teutonia'' (1872) LR 4 PC 171</ref><ref>''The Al Taha'' [1990] 2 LL R 117</ref><ref> ''Stag Line v Foscolo, Mango & Co'' [1932] AC 328</ref> <ref>''Scaramanga v Stamp'' (1880) 5 CPD 295</ref> a cargo-owner will have to claim on his own cargo policy. A claim having been paid, the assured's rights of claim will be [[Subrogation|subrogated]] to the insurer, who may consider proceeding against a party who has caused the damage.
A [[Ship-owner|shipowner]] may sue a [[Chartering (shipping)#Charter types|time-charterer]] or [[Chartering (shipping)|voyage-charterer]] in the event of breach of contract. For instance, if the charterer exceeds [[laytime]], [[demurrage]] will have to be paid; and if the charterer cannot comply with a [[Laytime|Notice of Readiness]] (NOR), the shipowner may [[Anticipatory repudiation|repudiate]] (cancel) the contract of carriage and claim [[damages]] for any loss.<ref>[[Maredelanto Compania Naviera SA v Bergbau-Handel GmbH]]|''The Mihalis Angelos''</ref>
==Carriage conventions== In most contracts of carriage the carrier has greater bargaining power than the shipper, and in the 19th century English judges developed rules to protect the weaker parties.<ref>''M'Andrew v Adams'' (1834) 1 Bing NC 29</ref> Beginning with the [[Hague Rules]], the various conventions set out to codify and develop such [[common law]] principles by providing an international set of basic standards to be met by the carrier, with a view to establishing a universal framework of legal rights and duties. In practice, however, the level of protection was actually reduced because of new provisions allowing the carrier to (i) limit his liability, and (ii) rely on a wide array of exemptions from liability <ref>...such as "[[Act of God]]", "[[Perils of the Sea]]" and "[[negligence]] in navigation or management of the ship").</ref><ref>e.g. Hague-Visby Rules Art. IV (1) & (2)</ref><ref>''Principles of the Carriage of Goods by Sea'' -Paul Todd</ref> Also, whereas up until about 1885,<ref>''The Glenfruin'' (1885) 10 PD 103</ref> the carrier's duties were deemed to be [[Strict liability|strict]], by 1905 the duty became one of "[[reasonable care]]" or "[[due diligence]]" only.<ref>''McFadden v Blue Star Line'' [1905] 1 KB 697</ref>
The Hague Rules of 1924 effectively [[Codification (law)|codified]], albeit in a diluted form, the English common law rules to protect the cargo owner against exploitation by the carrier. Nearly 50 years later, the [[Hague-Visby Rules|Hague-Visby]] "update" made few changes, so that the newer Rules still applied only to "tackle to tackle" carriage (i.e. carriage by sea) and the [[Intermodal container|container]] revolution of the 1950s was virtually ignored. The Hague-Visby Rules both excluded cabotage carriage, and declared that deck cargo and live animals were not to be considered as "goods" (although the [[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act 1971]] provided that cabotage, deck cargo and live animals are to be covered in English contracts).
The enormous list of exemptions to liability in Article IV made the Rules seem biased in favour of the carrier. As a result, The United Nations produced its own Hamburg Rules which were both more modern and fairer to cargo-owners; but while these have been enthusiastically adopted by developing nations, the wealthier ship-owning nations have stuck to Hague-Visby. In 2008 the final text of the Rotterdam Rules was agreed at [[UNCITRAL]].<ref> UNCITRAL: United Nations Commission of International Trade Law.</ref> These Rules are very extensive, with over 90 Articles against 11 in Hague-Visby. Although the Rotterdam Rules are up-to-date and address multimodal carriage, they have, nine years later, yet to be in force. It now seems doubtful that the Rotterdam Rules will ever be adopted, but there is a slim possibility that a cut-down version of the Rules ("Rotterdam Lite") might find favour.
China has effectively adopted the Hague Rules. The USA, which tends to shun conventions and instead rely on homespun legislation, has its own [[statutes]]. These comprise the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act (a mildly updated version of the Hague Rules for goods in foreign commerce), and the [[Harter Act]] (for mostly domestic carriage).<ref>Lexolology report [https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=04c1704f-05cd-4dc5-89c8-bb1a921dd13b]</ref>
==Relevant statutes and sources== * [[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act 1971]] - UK * [[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act 1992]] - UK * [[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act|Carriage of Goods by Sea Act - (USA)]] * [[Harter Act]] - USA
==References== {{reflist}}

This is a '''list of [[free-trade zone]]s''' by country: {{Expand list|date=February 2011}}Canada
==Africa==
===Morocco<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mce.gov.ma|title=Secrétariat d’Etat chargé du Commerce Extérieur|website=www.mce.gov.ma|access-date=2017-10-21}}</ref>=== * Tanger Free Zone * Atlantic Free Zone Kenitra * Free Zones at Tanger Med Ksar el Majaz Mellousa 1 and 2 * Free Zone in Dakhla and Laayoune: * Free Storage Zone of hydrocarbons: Kebdana and Nador
===Egypt=== [[Egypt]] has nine free-trade zones:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gafinet.org/English/Pages/FreeZones.aspx|title=The Egyptian Free Zones|publisher=Ahmed Beleity|year=2012}}</ref> * [[Alexandria]] Public free Zone * [[Damietta]] Public Free Zone * [[Ismailia]] Public Free Zone * [[Keft]] Public Free Zone * Media Production City Free Zone * [[Nasr City]] Public Free Zone * [[Port Said]] Public Free Zone * [[Shebin El Kom]] Public Free Zone * Suez Public Free Zone
===Djibouti=== *[[Djibouti]] Free Zone
===Gabon=== * Zone économique spéciale de [[Nkok]], at 30 km of [[Libreville]]
===Kenya=== According to the [[Kenya]] EPZ Authority the aim of the program is "to transform the economy from import substitution to a path of export led growth". "EPZs are designed to further integrate Kenya into the global supply chain and attract export-oriented investments in the zones, thus achieving its economic objectives of job creation, diversification and expansion of exports, increase in productive investments, technology transfer and creation of backward linkages between the zones and the domestic economy"."The program has contributed significantly to achieving these objectives with over 40 zones in place, close to 40,000 workers employed and contribution of 10.7 % of national exports. Over 70% of EPZ output is exported to the USA under AGOA".<ref name="KenyaEPZA"> {{cite web | last = Kenya | first = EPZA | title = Welcome to the Export Processing Zones Website | publisher = EPZA Kenya | date = 2012-10-17 | url = http://www.epzakenya.com/ | accessdate = 2012-11-04 }}</ref> These include: * [[Al-borj]] Kenya EPZ Ltd * Alltex EPZ Ltd * Apex Apparels EPZ Ltd * Ashton Apparel EPZ Ltd. * Baraka Apparel EPZ Ltd * Blue Bird Garments (K) EPZ Ltd * Blue Sky Films EPZ Ltd * California Link EPZ Ltd * Cybel Agric EPZ Ltd * De La Rue Currency & Security print EPZ Ltd * E.A. Gas EPZ Ltd * E.A Molasses EPZ Ltd * Earth Oil Kenya Proprietary EPZ Ltd * ET Elasto Tech EPZ Ltd * Film Studios EPZ Ltd. * Forum International EPZ Ltd. * Friends & Partners EPZ Ltd * Global Apparels (K) EPZ Ltd * Indu Farm EPZ Ltd. * Insight Digital Graphics EPZ Ltd. * Insta Products EPZ Ltd * Ivee Aqua EPZ Ltd. * Kenya Marine Contractors EPZ Ltd. * Kenya Vegext EPZ Ltd * Kevroe Plastics EPZ Ltd * LNC Apparels (K) EPZ Ltd * Logistic Container Center Mombasa EPZ Ltd. * Maximus EPZ Ltd * Mega Garments Industries (K) EPZ Ltd * JAR Kenya EPZ Ltd * Kapric Apparels EPZ Ltd. * Kencall EPZ Ltd * Kenya Fluorspar EP Ltd * Kenya Knit Garment EPZ Ltd * Middle East Texaco EPZ Ltd * Mirage Fashion Wear EPZ Ltd * MRC Nairobi EPZ Ltd. * Newland EPZ Ltd * Nodor Kenya EPZ Ltd. * Norbrook Africa EPZ Ltd. * Nutro Manufacturing EPZ Ltd * Oil Tanking EPZ Ltd * Penguin Paper & Book Co. EPZ Ltd * Plastex EPZ Ltd * Plastic Compounders EPZ Ltd. * Pontact Productions EPZ Ltd * Premium Machinery Distributors EPZ Ltd. * Protex EPZ Ltd. * Rising Sun (K) EPZ Lt * Rolex Garments EPZ Ltd. * Rosavie EPZ Ltd * Rupa Cotton Mills EPZ Ltd. * Sahara Stitch EPZ Ltd * Senior Best Garment EPZ Ltd * Shipmarc EPZ Ltd. * Shin Ace Garments EPZ Ltd. * Sin Lane (K) EPZ Ltd * Sinolink Kenya Garments Manufacturing EPZ Ltd * Supreme Plastics (Africa) EPZ Ltd * Tex Care Africa EPZ Ltd. * Twin Leaves EPZ Ltd. * United Aryan EPZ Ltd. * Upan Wasana EPZ Ltd * Wildlife Works EPZ Ltd * YKK Kenya EPZ Ltd

===China=== [[File:China (Tianjin) Pilot Free-Trade Zone Yujiapu.JPG|thumb|[[Tianjin Free-Trade Zone]]]] {{main|Special Economic Zones of the People's Republic of China}} *[[Tianjin Free-Trade Zone]] *[[Shanghai Free-Trade Zone]] *[[Fujian Free-Trade Zone]] *[[Guangdong Free-Trade Zone]] *[[Liaoning Free Trade Zone]]<ref>https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=6e373e5e-7d67-4f8c-af0b-d8f65d8db008</ref> *[[Zhejiang Zone]] *[[Henan Free Trade Zone]] *[[Hubei Free Trade Zone]] *[[Sichuan Free Trade Zone]] *[[Shaanxi Free Trade Zone]] *[[Chongqing Free Trade Zone]]
===India=== {{see also|List of Special Economic Zones in India}} * Kandla Special Economic Zone, India. India was one of the first in Asia to recognize the effectiveness of the Export Processing Zone (EPZ) model in promoting exports, with Asia's first EPZ set up in Kandla in 1965. With a view to overcome the shortcomings experienced on account of the multiplicity of controls and clearances; absence of world-class infrastructure, and an unstable fiscal regime and with a view to attract larger foreign investments in India, the Special Economic Zones (SEZs) Policy was announced in April 2000. SuRSEZ is the First Operating Zone in the private sector in India. The track record of SuRSEZ in the last 5 years speaks for itself. From a level of about Rs.62 crores in 2000-01, exports from SuRSEZ rose to Rs. 2400 crores in the year 2005-06. * Inspira Pharma and Renewable Energy Park, [[Aurangabad, Maharashtra|Aurangabad]], [[Maharashtra]], [[India]] * Sricity Multi product SEZ, part of [[Sricity]] which is a developing satellite city in [[Andhra Pradesh]] & [[Tamil Nadu]], [[India]] * [[Arshiya International Ltd#Free Trade & Warehousing Zones (FTWZs)|Arshiya International Ltd]], India's first Free Trade and Warehousing Zone<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2010-08-18/news/27567234_1_ftwzs-arshiya-international-warehousing|title=Arshiya launches India's first FTWZ in Mumbai|publisher=The Economic Times|date=2010-08-18}}</ref> The largest multi-product free-trade and warehousing infrastructure in India. Arshiya's first 165-acre FTWZ is operational in Panvel, Mumbai, and is to be followed by one in Khurja near Delhi. Arshiya's Mega Logistics Hub at Khurja to have 135 acre FTWZ, 130 acre Industrial and Distribution Hub (Distripark) & 50 acre Rail siding. Arshiya International will be developing three more Free Trade and Warehousing zones in Central, South and East of India. * [[Cochin Special Economic Zone]] is a Special Economic Zone in Cochin, in the State of Kerala in southwest India, set up for export- oriented ventures. The Special Economic Zone is a foreign territory within India with special rules for facilitating foreign direct investment. The Zone is run directly by the Government of India. Cochin SEZ is a multi-product Zone. Cochin is strategically located. It is in southwest India, just 11 nautical miles off the international sea route from Europe to the Pacific Rim. Cochin is being developed by the Dubai Ports International as a container transhipment terminal with direct sailings to important markets of the world, which could position it as Hub for South Asia. * [[Hardware Park, Hyderabad]] * [[Madras Export Processing Zone]]
===Indonesia=== * [[Batam]] Free Trade Zone * [[Bagansiapiapi]] Special Economic Zone * [[Larantuka]] Free Trade Zone * [[Pariaman]] Free Trade Zone * [[Bangunrejo]] Special Economic Zone * [[Teluknaga]] Special Economic Zone * [[Padang]] Free Trade Zone

===Georgia=== * [[Kutaisi Free Industrial Zone]]
Free Industrial Zone is the type of a free zone envisaged by Customs Code of Georgia where the business-friendly regulations and favourable tax and customs system apply. FIZ is singled out during the limited time period for economical activity and the companies operating therein are subordinated to special regime, which is favourable from legal and commercial point of view.
Perhaps the main privilege of FIZ which attracts business investments in Georgia and makes the place the most favorable to do business is the favorable tax and customs framework, which is as follows:
· FIZ incorporated entities are exempt from Property Tax; · No VAT applies to goods produced in other country imported in FIZ; · No VAT applies to transactions carried out among FIZ incorporated entities; · Supply of goods/services among enterprises of FIZ is VAT exempt; · No Customs duty applies to goods produced in other country, imported in FIZ; · Export of goods produced in FIZ within the territory of Georgia is free from Customs duty; · No foreign exchange controls, trade barriers of quotas; · No restrictions on capital repatriation; · Profit gained by an international enterprise from an activity carried out in FIZ is exempt from Profit Tax
