{{Infobox person | name = Lou Dobbs | image = Lou Dobbs by Gage Skidmore.jpg | birth_name = Louis Carl Dobbs | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1945|9|24}} | birth_place = [[Childress County, Texas]], [[United States|U.S.]] | caption = Dobbs in February 2015. | death_place = | spouse = Debi Lee Roth-Segura | occupation = Talk radio host, news anchor, managing editor | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] (until 2001) Independent (2001–present)| residence = [[Wantage Township, New Jersey]], U.S. | children = 4 | education = [[Harvard University]], B.A. [[University of Idaho College of Law]], [[Left before completion]] }}
'''Louis Carl "Lou" Dobbs''' <ref name="BirthRecord"/> (born September 24, 1945) is an American television commentator, author, radio show host, [[Conspiracy theory|conspiracy theorist]], and the anchor of ''[[Lou Dobbs Tonight]]'' on [[Fox Business Network]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/25/media/lou-dobbs-fake-bombs/index.html|title=Fox Business Network host Lou Dobbs peddles conspiracy theory about suspicious packages|last=Business|first=Oliver Darcy, CNN|work=CNN|access-date=2018-12-01}}</ref>
Dobbs started working with [[CNN]] at its inception in 1980, serving as a reporter and network vice president. On the air, he served as host and [[managing editor]] of the network's business program, ''Moneyline'', which premiered in 1980. The show was renamed ''Lou Dobbs Tonight'' in 2003. Dobbs resigned from CNN for a short period of time in 1999 but rejoined the network in 2001. He resigned once again in November 2009. In 2011, he joined the Fox Business Network, resuming and anchoring his show, ''Lou Dobbs Tonight''. He is the former host of a syndicated [[USRN|U.S. Radio Network]] program, ''Lou Dobbs Radio''. Dobbs has authored several books since 2001.
Dobbs describes himself politically as an "independent populist". He is known for his pro-Trump coverage, anti-immigration views, promotion of Barack Obama [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|birther conspiracy theories]], and opposition to [[NAFTA]].
==Background and family life== Born in [[Childress County, Texas]], Dobbs is the son of Frank Dobbs, a co-owner of a [[propane]] business, and Lydia Mae (née Hensley), a bookkeeper.<ref name="BirthRecord">{{cite web| url = http://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?db=txbirthindex&h=4102858&ti=0&indiv=try | title = Texas Birth Index, 1903-1997 (Ancestry.com database on-line) | accessdate = 2008-03-24 }}</ref> When Dobbs was 12, his father's propane business failed and the family moved to [[Rupert, Idaho]].<ref name="Madashell">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/fact/content/articles/061204fa_fact1 |title=Mad as Hell: Lou Dobbs's populist crusade |accessdate=2007-01-17 |last=Auletta |first=Ken |date=2006-12-04 |work=[[The New Yorker]] }}</ref> He attended [[Minico High School]] in [[Minidoka County, Idaho|Minidoka County]], where he played [[Offensive tackle|tackle]] on the [[high school football|football]] team, played the [[sousaphone]] in the band, and served as [[student body president]].<ref name="Secret">{{cite web | url = http://www.american.com/archive/2006/november/lou-dobbs | last = Mullins | first = Luke | date = 2006-11-28 | title = The Secret Life of Lou Dobbs | work = The American | accessdate = 2007-06-03 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070604144247/http://www.american.com/archive/2006/november/lou-dobbs | archivedate = 2007-06-04 | df = }}</ref> Although accepted at the [[University of Idaho]] and [[Idaho State University]], he was persuaded by the staff at Minico High to apply to [[Harvard University]], where he was accepted and later graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[economics]] in 1967.<ref name="Secret"/> While at Harvard, Dobbs lived in [[Quincy House (Harvard College)|Quincy House]] and was elected to the [[Owl Club]].
After graduating, Dobbs worked for federal [[anti-poverty program]]s in [[Boston]] and Washington, D.C., then returned to Idaho. He briefly attended [[law school]] at the [[University of Idaho College of Law|UI College of Law]] in [[Moscow, Idaho]] and then worked as a [[cash-management]] specialist for [[Union Bank of California]] in Los Angeles. He married his high school sweetheart in 1969, and in 1970 their first son was born. Dobbs moved to [[Yuma, Arizona]], and got a job as a police and fire reporter for [[KBLU (AM)|KBLU]]. By the mid-1970s he was a [[television anchor]] and [[reporter]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], and he later joined [[Seattle]]'s [[KING-TV]]. In 1979, he was contacted by a recruiter for [[Ted Turner]], who was in the process of forming CNN.<ref name="Madashell"/> Dobbs divorced his first wife in 1981 and is now married to Debi Lee Segura, a former CNN [[sports anchor]]. The couple raised four children together.<ref name="Lou Dobbs Biography – Biography.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.biography.com/search/article.do?id=225197 |title=Lou Dobbs Biography |publisher=Biography.com |accessdate=2018-04-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108150646/http://www.biography.com/search/article.do?id=225197|archivedate=2009-01-08}}</ref> Dobbs resides on a {{convert|300|acre|km2|adj=on}} horse farm in [[Wantage Township, New Jersey]].<ref name="Lou Dobbs Biography – Biography.com"/>
==Career==
=== CNN === Dobbs joined CNN when it launched in 1980, serving as its chief [[economics]] [[correspondent]] and as [[Host (radio)#Television presenter|host]] of the business news program ''[[Lou Dobbs Tonight|Moneyline]]'' on CNN. Dobbs also served as a [[corporate executive]] for CNN, as its executive vice president and as a member of CNN's executive committee. He founded [[CNN fn]] (CNN financial news), serving as its president and anchoring the program ''Business Unusual'', which examined business creativity and leadership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsbios.com/newslum/dobbs.htm |title=Business News Luminaries |publisher=Newsbios.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-12}}</ref>
===Departure and founding of Space.com=== Dobbs repeatedly clashed with [[Rick Kaplan]], who became president of CNN in 1997. Dobbs said Kaplan, noted friend of then president [[Bill Clinton]], was "clearly partisan" and "was pushing Clinton stories", while Kaplan said Dobbs was "a very difficult person to work with".<ref name="Madashell"/>
On April 20, 1999, CNN was covering Clinton's speech in [[Littleton, Colorado]], following the [[Columbine High School massacre]]. Dobbs ordered the producer to cut away from the speech and return to broadcast ''Moneyline''.<ref name="Madashell"/> Dobbs was countermanded by Kaplan, who ordered CNN to return to the speech. Kaplan later said, "Tell me what journalistic reason there was not to cover the president at Columbine soon after the shootings? Everyone else was doing it". Dobbs announced on the air that "CNN President Rick Kaplan wants us to return to Littleton". A few days later, Dobbs announced that he was leaving the network to start [[Space.com]], a website devoted to [[Astronautics|astronautical]] news.<ref name="Madashell"/> Dobbs was subsequently replaced as host of ''Moneyline'' by [[Willow Bay]] and [[Stuart Varney]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timewarner.com/corp/newsroom/pr/0,20812,667811,00.html |title=MONEYLINE Launches Bicoastal News Format |publisher=Time Warner |date=2000-08-22 |accessdate=2010-04-12}}</ref>
===Return to CNN=== Kaplan left CNN in August 2000, and Dobbs returned the following year, at the behest of his friend and CNN founder [[Ted Turner]], becoming host and [[managing editor]] of the new and initially more general news program ''Lou Dobbs Reporting'', which later became ''CNN News Sunday Morning''. He also regained the helm of the newly renamed ''Lou Dobbs Moneyline'' (which became ''Lou Dobbs Tonight'' in June 2003).<ref>{{Cite news| first = Peter | last = Johnson | title='Lou Dobbs Moneyline' gets a new moniker | date = 2003-06-09 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/columnist/mediamix/2003-06-09-media-mix_x.htm | work = [[USA Today]] | accessdate = 2007-01-17 }}</ref>
===Exit from CNN=== On the November 11, 2009 edition of his nightly broadcast ''Lou Dobbs Tonight'', Dobbs announced his immediate departure from CNN, ending a nearly thirty-year career at the network, citing plans to "pursue new opportunities".<ref name="Update: Lou Dobbs to Quit CNN">{{Cite news|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/11/lou-dobbs-to-depart-cnn/|title=Update: Lou Dobbs to Quit CNN|last1=Stelter|first1=Brian|date=2009-11-11|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-11-11|last2=Carter|first2=Bill}}</ref><ref name = "CNN1">{{Cite book |title=Anchor Lou Dobbs departs CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/11/11/lou.dobbs.leaving/index.html |accessdate=November 11, 2009 |date=November 11, 2009<!--, 20:44 (EST) -->|work=CNN website |publisher=CNN |location=New York, NY, U.S.A. |quote=CNN's Lou Dobbs stepped down from his controversial role as an advocacy anchor at the network at the end of his show Wednesday night after announcing plans to seek a more activist role.}}</ref> CNN President [[Jonathan Klein (CNN)|Jon Klein]] said that Dobbs' departure was not a result of organized opposition to Dobbs' viewpoints.<ref name="YahooNews1">{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091115010049/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091112/ap_on_en_tv/us_tv_lou_dobbs|title=Advocacy groups claim victory after Dobbs leaves|date=November 15, 2009}}</ref><ref name = "LATimes1">{{Cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/11/lou-dobbs-cnn.html |title=Lou Dobbs abruptly quits CNN on the air – video |work=Los Angeles Times |date=2009-11-11 |accessdate=2010-04-12|page=m}}</ref>
In July 2009, controversy around Dobbs began when he was the only mainstream news anchor to give airtime to the [[birther]] conspiracy theory.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/08/02/lou-dobbs-a-publicity-nig_n_249466.html |title=Lou Dobbs A "Publicity Nightmare" For CNN: AP |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2009-08-02|accessdate=2010-04-12 |first=Rachel |last=Weiner}}</ref> Several liberal advocacy groups, including [[Media Matters for America|Media Matters]], and the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] criticized Dobbs for his reporting. The controversy eventually caused CNN President [[Jonathan Klein (CNN)|Jon Klein]] to rein Dobbs in via an internal memorandum.<ref>{{cite web |last=Ariens |first=Chris |url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/cnn/jon_klein_on_birthers_it_seems_this_story_is_dead_122546.asp |title=Jon Klein on Birthers: "It Seems This Story is Dead" – mediabistro.com: TVNewser |publisher=mediabistro.com |date=2009-07-24 |accessdate=2010-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100425075638/http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/cnn/jon_klein_on_birthers_it_seems_this_story_is_dead_122546.asp |archivedate=2010-04-25 |df= }}</ref> In September, advocates challenged Dobbs for appearing at a conference organized by the anti-immigration group Federation for American Immigration Reform. Multiple campaigns were launched, including "Drop Dobbs" ([[New Democrat Network|NDN]], [[Media Matters for America|Media Matters]]), and "Basta Dobbs" ([[Presente.org]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bastadobbs.com/blog/2009/sep/16/latino-leaders-across-us-demand-cnn-drop-controver/ |title=Basta Dobbs : Latino Leaders Across U.S. Demand CNN Drop Controversial Host Lou Dobbs for Extremist Ties |publisher=BastaDobbs.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-12}}</ref>
The campaigns also attacked CNN for alleged hypocrisy towards Latinos, citing CNN's ''Latino in America'' special as incompatible with their continued support of Dobbs. The campaigns generated considerable anti-Dobbs press,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.impre.com/eldiariony/noticias/locales/2009/10/22/hispanos-a-cnn--eres-latino-o--155229-1.html |title=El Diario La Prensa NY – noticias de Nueva York – impre.com – Hispanos a CNN: ¿eres latino o anti-latino? |publisher=impre.com |date=2009-10-22 |accessdate=2010-04-12}}</ref> and are credited by some{{Who|date=September 2010}} as pushing Dobbs out.
Dobbs was reportedly paid $8 million in severance pay when he left CNN prior to his contract being due for renewal.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Shain |first=Michael |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/source_cnn_wanted_lou_out_LOBEhi0KhBVvzqxDoxbPWI |title=Source: CNN wanted Lou out |publisher=Nypost.com |date=2009-11-16 |accessdate=2010-04-12}}</ref>
After Dobbs left CNN in 2009, he gave an interview where he did not rule out the possibility of running for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012]], saying the final decision would rest with his wife.<ref>Memmot, Mark (2009-11-24) [https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2009/11/lou_dobbs_white_house_independ.html "Lou Dobbs Hints At White House Run In 2012 As An Independent"], NPR.org. Retrieved 2009-11-24.</ref><ref>Condon, Stephanie (2009-11-24) [http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2009/11/23/politics/politicalhotsheet/entry5750619.shtml?tag=twitter "Lou Dobbs for President in 2012?"], CBS News.com. Retrieved 2009-11-24.</ref> Former Senator [[Dean Barkley]] said he thought Dobbs should run for president.<ref name="barkley">{{cite web|url=http://minnesotaindependent.com/50490/barkley-dobbs-would-be-perfect-ip-party-candidate-for-prez|title=Barkley: Dobbs would be 'perfect' IP Party candidate for prez|accessdate=November 28, 2009}}</ref>
===Radio=== From 2009 to 2012, Dobbs hosted ''Lou Dobbs Radio'' on [[United Stations Radio Networks]]. The three-hour daily show had affiliates in several major markets, including its [[flagship (radio)|flagship station]] ([[WOR (AM)|WOR]]) in New York City, [[Washington D.C.]] ([[WJFK (AM)|WHFS]]), [[Miami]] ([[WZAB]]-AM) and the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] ([[KDOW]]), as well as stations such as [[WGNY (AM)|WGNY-AM]] in [[Newburgh (city), New York|Newburgh, New York]]. The show was guest-centered and featured political discussion and listener calls. It aired from 2 to 5 p.m. Eastern, directly competing with ''[[The Sean Hannity Show]]'', ''The Tom Sullivan Show'' and ''[[The Dave Ramsey Show (radio program)|The Dave Ramsey Show]]''. Dobbs also hosts the financially themed ''Lou Dobbs Minute'' on the same network.
In June 2008, Dobbs reached an agreement with [[Business Talk Radio Network]] to carry a rebroadcast of the show from 7 p.m. to 10 p.m. Eastern, displacing [[Bruce Williams (talk radio host)|Bruce Williams]]. Dobbs' show was also carried live on [[CRN Digital Talk Radio Networks]].
Dobbs was among the hosts who tried out for the position vacated by the cancellation of ''[[Imus in the Morning]]'' on [[WFAN (AM)|WFAN]], a position that was eventually filled by ''[[Boomer and Carton in the Morning]]''. Dobbs mentioned on his radio show that he is currently seeking a position in the [[US Department of Treasury]] during the economic crisis. He stated that he believed he could "do more good than the clowns currently in position."
Dobbs also is a regular columnist in ''[[Money (magazine)|Money]]'' magazine, ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'', and the ''[[New York Daily News]]''.<ref name="Madashell"/>
===Current show on Fox Business Network===
On November 10, 2010, Fox Business Network announced that Dobbs would host a show on the channel.<ref>[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2010/11/lou-dobbs-joining-fox-business-network.html Lou Dobbs joining Fox Business Network] ''Los Angeles Times'' November 10, 2010</ref> The network announced on March 3, 2011 the start date, show title, and time slot of Dobbs' new show. Titled ''[[Lou Dobbs Tonight]]'' the program debuted on March 14, 2011, airing at 7 PM Eastern. That is the same title and time slot that Dobbs' old CNN show had.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/03/lou-dobbs-fox-business-sh_n_831033.html Lou Dobbs' new Fox Business show gets a start date and a name] ''The Huffington Post'' March 3, 2011</ref>
===Other appearances===
Since 2009, Dobbs has made regular appearances to discuss issues on other news network programs including CNBC's ''[[The Kudlow Report]]'' and Fox News Channel's ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]''. On October 5, 2010, Dobbs made a guest appearance on an episode of ''[[The Good Wife (TV series)|The Good Wife]]'', entitled "Double Jeopardy",<ref>{{IMDb title|1632297|The Good Wife, Double Jeopardy}} October 5, 2010</ref> in which he plays himself as a client in search of a new law firm to represent his legal interests.
==Political views and controversies==
Dobbs was a lifelong Republican.<ref name=":0" /> However, he later registered as an Independent following a break with the Bush Administration.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mediaite.com/tv/lou-dobbs-says-it-may-be-time-to-declare-war-outright-against-the-deep-state/|title=Lou Dobbs Says 'It May Be Time to Declare War Outright Against the Deep State'|author=|date=|website=www.mediaite.com|accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref> Dobbs is known for his anti-immigration views,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/apr/28/usa.television|title=Hispanic congressmen demand corporate action against CNN host|last=Schor|first=Elana|date=2008-04-28|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-14|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> warnings about Islamist terror, and his opposition to free trade.<ref name=":0">{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/economy/employment/2005-02-22-dobbs-usat_x.htm | work=USA Today | first1=Michael | last1=McCarthy | title=Dobbs blasts outsourcing | date=2005-02-25}}</ref> He is known for his pro-Trump coverage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/09/14/media/pro-trump-media-daca-dreamers/index.html|title=Pro-Trump media incensed over reports he struck deal with Dems on Dreamers|last=Darcy|first=Oliver|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/trump-media-democrats-debt-deal-2017-9?r=US&IR=T|title=Right-wing media praises Trump's deal with the Democrats and rips Republican leaders|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-10-14|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://amp.thedailybeast.com/donald-trump-cherishes-lou-dobbs-so-much-he-puts-him-on-speakerphone-for-oval-office-meetings|title=Donald Trump 'Cherishes' Lou Dobbs So Much He Puts Him on Speakerphone for Oval Office Meetings|website=amp.thedailybeast.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-02}}</ref> According to ''The Daily Beast'', by 2018, Dobbs had turned into a "full-on conservative nationalist-populist and culture warrior."<ref name=":5" />
===Birtherism=== Dobbs promoted the [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|false conspiracy theory]] that [[Barack Obama]] was not born in the United States.<ref name=":5" /><ref>''[[Guardian Unlimited]]'', 29 July 2009, [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2009/jul/29/birthers-obama-citizenship-republicans Birthers are citizens of Idiot America]</ref> His willingness to raise the "[[birther]]" issue repeatedly<ref>"a lot of questions remaining, and seemingly the questions won't go away because they haven't been dealt with". ''Lou Dobbs Tonight'', CNN, 20 July 2009, [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0907/20/ldt.01.html transcript]</ref> even though CNN itself considered it a "discredited rumor",<ref>''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 22 July 2009, [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-onthemedia22-2009jul22,0,3061950.column?page=1 Lou Dobbs and the canard over President Obama's birth]</ref> led the ''[[Washington Post]]'''s TV critic to remark that this "explains their upcoming documentary: 'The World: Flat. We Report – You Decide.'"<ref>''[[Washington Post]]'', 29 July 2009, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/28/AR2009072802817.html An Old Rumor Bears Repeating On CNN]</ref> The issue had come up in 2008 during the Presidential campaign, and had largely disappeared from the media spotlight until Dobbs picked up the issue again.<ref>''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', 25 July 2009, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/barackobama/5907183/Right-Wing-US-conspiracists-question-Obamas-birth-certificate.html Right Wing US conspiracists question Obama's birth certificate]</ref> His statements in support of these conspiracy theories were dubbed "racist" and "[[defamation|defamatory]]" by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/news/item.jsp?aid=390|title=''Southern Poverty Law Center'' Letter from SPLC President, Richard Cohen to CNN President Jonathan Klein, July 24, 2009, accessed 2 August 2009|date=2009-07-24|publisher=Splcenter.org|accessdate=2010-04-12}}</ref><ref>''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 25 July 2009, [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-cnnobama25-2009jul25,0,3939176.story CNN chief addresses Obama birth controversy]</ref> The controversy led to [[Media Matters]] airing ads critical of Dobbs and of CNN,<ref>''[[Baltimore Sun]]'' TV blog, August 2009, [http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/zontv/2009/08/lou_dobbs_cnn_birthers_obama_m.html Lou Dobbs becomes a real problem for CNN]</ref> and to [[Jon Stewart]] mocking Dobbs on the satirical [[Comedy Central]] [[television series]] ''[[The Daily Show]]''.<ref>''Gawker'', 23 July 2009, [http://gawker.com/5320976/jon-stewart-to-lou-dobbs-do-you-even-watch-your-own-f+ing-network Jon Stewart to Lou Dobbs: 'Do You Even Watch Your Own F-ing Network?!'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090804092623/http://gawker.com/5320976/jon-stewart-to-lou-dobbs-do-you-even-watch-your-own-f%2Bing-network|date=August 4, 2009}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' said that Dobbs had "become a publicity nightmare for CNN, embarrassed his boss and hosted a show that seemed to contradict the network's 'no bias' brand."<ref>''[[The New York Times]]'', 3 August 2009, [https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2009/08/03/arts/AP-US-TV-Lou-Dobbs.html Lou Dobbs Challenges His Own CNN Network]</ref>
===Immigration=== Dobbs holds anti-immigration views.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-essential-washington-updates-trump-faults-his-justice-department-on-1521633789-htmlstory.html|title=Trump faults his Justice Department on Arizona 'Dreamer' case, citing Lou Dobbs|last=Bierman|first=Noah|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-10-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/lou-dobbs-quits-cnn-just-like-that-2009-11?IR=T|title=Lou Dobbs Quits CNN, Just Like That|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-10-20}}</ref> Dobbs has been strongly opposed to both [[Illegal immigration to the United States|illegal immigration]] and foreign worker programs as the [[H-1B visa]] program and [[foreign worker|guest-worker]] programs. In a 2006 article, Dobbs expressed frustration at failed legislation to build a southern "border fence to stop the flow of illegal aliens and drugs across our borders." He argued that the "true victims of corporate America's lust for cheap labor" were "American working men and women, taxpayers all."<ref name="Dobbs_CNN_2006_wall">{{cite news |title=Five-weeks off for 'do-nothing Congress' |author=Lou Dobbs |work=CNN |date=August 2, 2006 |location=New York}}</ref>
Dobbs' show has made factually incorrect claims, such as the one that illegal immigrants were responsible for bringing 7,000 new cases of [[leprosy]] to the United States in a three-year period, where the actual timeframe was over the last thirty years.<ref>James L. Krahenbuhl, the director of the [[Bureau of Primary Health Care#National Hansen's Disease Program|National Hansen's Disease Program]], cited in {{Cite news| first = David| last = Leonhardt| authorlink = David Leonhardt| title = Truth, Fiction and Lou Dobbs | date=2007-05-30 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/30/business/30leonhardt.html |newspaper= New York Times | accessdate=2010-05-11}}</ref> In addressing the leprosy issue, Dobbs in May 2007 compared his critics from the left and right political spectrums to "[[communism|commies]]" and "[[fascism|fascists]]."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003592316|title=Lou Dobbs Responds to 'Scurrilous' Attack By 'NYT'|date=2007-05-31|work=[[Editor & Publisher]]|accessdate=2007-06-03}}</ref>
Dobbs has criticized local officials for their approach to border security. In October 2007 he labeled then-[[Governor of New York|New York Governor]] [[Eliot Spitzer]] an "idiot" for advocating the issuance of [[driver's license]]s to illegal immigrants.<ref>{{Cite news | first = Larry | last = McShane | title = Dobbs Shows No Love For Guv | date = 2007-10-29 | url = http://www.courant.com/news/local/hc-spitzer1029.artoct29,0,2408884.story | work = courant.com | accessdate = 2007-10-29 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071029211705/http://www.courant.com/news/local/hc-spitzer1029.artoct29,0,2408884.story | archivedate = 2007-10-29 | df = }}</ref> [[Hillary Clinton]] labeled Dobbs' illegal immigration segments as having "all that hot air."<ref>{{cite web |author=SteveK on Jan 03, 2008 03:49 PM |url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/cnn/dobbs_fires_back_at_clinton_for_hot_air_comment_74182.asp |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130128141653/http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/cnn/dobbs_fires_back_at_clinton_for_hot_air_comment_74182.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-28 |title=Dobbs Fires Back at Clinton For "Hot Air" Comment – mediabistro.com: TVNewser |publisher=mediabistro.com |date=2008-01-03 |accessdate=2010-04-12 }}</ref>
At about 10:30 a.m. on October 5, 2009, a bullet struck Dobbs' home as his wife stood outside it.<ref name=Shot-fired>{{Cite news|author=Joshua Rhett Miller |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,570296,00.html |title=Police Probe Shot Fired at Home of CNN's Lou Dobbs |publisher=FOXNews.com |date= 2009-10-29|accessdate=2010-04-12}}</ref> The bullet struck the vinyl siding of their attic without penetrating the vinyl and fell to the ground.<ref name="huffingtonpost.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/isabel-macdonald/nj-law-enforcement-appear_b_339696.html |title=NJ Law Enforcement Appear to Contradict Dobbs' Version of Gunfire Incident |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2009-10-30|accessdate=2010-04-12 |first=Isabel |last=MacDonald}}</ref> Dobbs attributed the incident to his stance against [[amnesty]] for illegal immigrants.<ref name=Shot-fired/> The [[New Jersey State Police]] troopers' account of the incident attributed it to a stray bullet from a hunter in the vicinity.<ref name="huffingtonpost.com"/>
In a November 2009 interview with [[Telemundo]], Dobbs said that the U.S. needed a "rational, effective humane policy" for immigration that included enhanced border security and also "the ability to legalize illegal immigrants on certain conditions."<ref>Angie Drobnic Holan, [http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2009/nov/30/lou-dobbs/did-lou-dobbs-oppose-amnesty-he-doesnt-oppose-it-n/ Did Lou Dobbs oppose amnesty? He doesn't oppose it now], Politifact (November 30, 2009).</ref><ref>Peter Wallsten, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125910998942663259 Dobbs Reaches Out to Latinos, With Politics in Mind], ''Wall Street Journalist'' (November 25, 2009).</ref>
In March 2009, Dobbs said he thought that there should not be a [[St. Patricks Day]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thinkprogress.org/lou-dobbs-attacks-st-patricks-day-how-about-an-american-day-e61c94b1d3aa|title=Lou Dobbs attacks St. Patrick's Day: 'How about an American day?'|date=18 March 2009|work=[[ThinkProgress]]}}</ref>
In October 2010, ''[[The Nation]]'' published the results of a yearlong investigation detailing undocumented workers who had worked on Dobbs' personal properties. The labor involved upkeep of Dobbs' multimillion-dollar estates in [[New Jersey]] and [[Florida]], including the horses belonging to his daughter, Hillary, a champion show jumper. The article featured interviews with five immigrants who had worked without papers on Dobbs' properties. Dobbs and his daughter had declined to comment to ''The Nation'' as part of the story.<ref name="amhypocrite">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/155209/lou-dobbs-american-hypocrite?page=full|title=Lou Dobbs, American Hypocrite|last=MacDonald|first=Isabel|date=2010-10-06|work=[[The Nation]]|accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> Speaking to the [[Associated Press]], Dobbs referred to the article as "a political assault," claiming it was a lie that he hired illegal immigrants. He said: "I have never, do not now, and never will."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/10/07/AR2010100704043.html Report: Illegal Labor Worked at Dobbs' homes] AP via Washington Post; October 7, 2010.</ref>
In November 2018, Dobbs falsely claimed that "many" undocumented immigrants voted in the 2018 mid-term elections and that they had an "immense impact."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2018/nov/16/lou-dobbs/no-evidence-many-illegal-immigrants-voted-midterm-/|title=No evidence ‘many’ illegal immigrants voted in midterms|work=@politifact|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2018/11/16/lou-dobbs-casually-makes-up-story-that-many-illegal-immigrants-voted-midterms-had-immense-impact/|title=Lou Dobbs casually makes up story that ‘many’ illegal immigrants voted in midterms and had ‘immense impact’|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
Dobbs' critics, including columnist [[James K. Glassman]], author of ''[[Dow 36,000]]'' and member of the [[American Enterprise Institute]] think tank, have accused him of inciting [[xenophobia]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tcsdaily.com/article.aspx?id=022206H|title=Good for America|last=Glassman|first=James K|date=2006-02-23|work=TCS Daily|accessdate=2007-06-03|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070512050634/http://www.tcsdaily.com/article.aspx?id=022206H|archivedate=2007-05-12|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Others have accused him of [[Hispanophobia]], a charge he denies<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=33815|title=Lou Dobbs's Dubious Guest List|last=Berkowitz|first=Bill|date=2006-06-30|work=Inter Press Service News Agency|accessdate=2007-01-17|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061115010358/http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=33815|archivedate=2006-11-15|deadurl=yes|publisher=|pages=|language=|lcoauthors=|df=}}</ref> and one which he has said offends him deeply, as his wife Debi Segura is a [[Mexican-American]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/05/03/60minutes/main2758082.shtml?source=search_story|title=Lou Dobbs, "Advocacy" Journalist?|date=2007-05-06|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=2007-06-03}}</ref>
=== Pro-Trump views === On his show ''Lou Dobbs Tonight'', Dobbs stopped short of a full endorsement of Presidential candidate [[Donald Trump]], saying, "Whatever you think of Trump, whatever your politics, Trump has taken on enormous risk and threats in seeking the presidency ... promised to restore the voice of the people ... and a government that will respect all that our Constitution assures." Dobbs has since endorsed Donald Trump.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.facebook.com/LouDobbsTonight/videos/10153688766037951/|title=Political and business establishment intensifying its assault on Donald J. Trump|date=2016-06-03|work=Facebook|accessdate=2016-06-03}}</ref> In October 2017, Dobbs said that the Trump presidency "may be the most accomplished in modern American history."<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-updates-trump-tweets-lou-dobbs-accomplished-htmlstory.html|title=Everything President Trump has tweeted (and what it was about)|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-10-14|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> Trump praised Dobbs in return.<ref name=":1" /> Later that month, Dobbs interviewed Trump, with numerous observers describing Dobbs's interview style as fawning and sycophantic.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/10/26/16552362/lou-dobbs-trump-transcript|title=Lou Dobbs's Trump interview is a masterpiece of sycophancy and nonsense|work=Vox|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/lou-dobbs-trump-interview_us_59f1209ce4b0438859151b62|title=Fox's Lou Dobbs Lets Trump Take Over Interview To Rant About Fake News|last=Reilly|first=Mollie|date=2017-10-26|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-fox-business-network-lou-dobbs-693411|title=Lou Dobbs tells Donald Trump he is "one of the most loved and respected" presidents in history|date=2017-10-26|work=Newsweek|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en}}</ref> Dobbs opened the interview with "You have accomplished so much", and later said to Trump that he was "one of the most loved and respected" presidents "in history."<ref name=":2" /> The ''New York Times'' described the interview as a love-fest and "courtier-like session", as Dobbs "didn't so much ask questions as open his mouth and let rose petals fall out".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/10/arts/television/president-trump-finds-his-tv-niche-in-softball-interviews.html|title=President Trump Finds His TV Niche in Softball Interviews|last=Poniewozik|first=James|date=2017-11-10|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-11-10|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Dobbs has been described as a "close informal adviser to President Donald Trump."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/lou-dobbs-tweet-conspiracy-theory-democrats-mail-bombs-2018-10?r=UK&IR=T|title=Lou Dobbs promotes conspiracy theory that Democrats sent explosive devices to Clinton, Obama, and Soros to improve midterm chances|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}}</ref>
On October 13, 2016, Dobbs publicized by [[Twitter]] a link which contained the address and phone number of a woman who was among several who had come forward with allegations of being sexually assaulted by Republican Presidential candidate Donald Trump.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/on-media/2016/10/fox-anchor-tweets-trump-accusers-address-and-phone-number-229738|title=Lou Dobbs tweets Trump accuser's address and phone number|publisher=[[Politico]]}}</ref>
Trump repeatedly calls Dobbs to get his views on various policy issues. In 2017 Trump patched Dobbs into senior-level [[Oval Office]] meetings multiple times, sometimes interrupting officials to ask for Dobbs' opinions.<ref name=":5" />
Dobbs is a proponent of the [[Deep state in the United States|Deep State conspiracy theory]]. In January 2018, Dobbs called for a "war" on the "Deep State", which he described as the FBI and the Department of Justice.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/media/370469-lou-dobbs-its-time-to-declare-war-on-deep-state#.WmlNOdL_MzY.twitter|title=Lou Dobbs: 'May be time to declare war' on 'deep state'|last=Anapol|first=Avery|date=2018-01-24|work=TheHill|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> Dobbs said that the FBI and DOJ had destroyed evidence and that they were clandestinely working to bring down the Trump presidency.<ref name=":3" /> In June 2018, Dobbs promoted a conspiracy which originated on Reddit and the far-right conspiracy website Gateway Pundit that "the FBI May have initiated a number of spies into the Trump campaign as early as December of 2015."<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/06/06/politics/trump-fbi-texts-conspiracy-theory/index.html|title=From Reddit to Trump: How the President latched onto a conspiracy theory|last=CNN|first=Jeremy Herb and Manu Raju,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> Shortly after Dobbs promoted the unfounded conspiracy theory, Trump retweeted Dobbs' assertion and praised Dobbs for a "great interview".<ref name=":6" /> In July 2018, Dobbs said that Special Counsel Robert Mueller was on a "jihad" against Trump, and accused him of seeking to "subvert" and "overthrow" Trump's presidency.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/fox-host-lou-dobbs-mueller-trump-2018-7?r=US&IR=T|title='The hell with Mueller': Fox host Lou Dobbs says the special counsel is on 'jihad' against Trump|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en}}</ref>
After Trump criticized Attorney General Jeff Sessions for not investigating alleged abuses of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act in the investigation on Russian interference in the 2016 election, Dobbs attacked Sessions, saying that he had become physically or mentally unwell.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/fox-news-host-lou-dobbs-jeff-sessions-has-fallen-ill-needs-to-resign|title=Fox News Host Lou Dobbs: Jeff Sessions Has 'Fallen Ill,' Needs to Resign|last=Tani|first=Maxwell|date=2018-03-04|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-03-04|language=en}}</ref> Dobbs said, "Sessions has fallen ill, he's incapacitated in some fashion, or he's been coopted or captured: to preserve any dignity, for the good of the country he needs to resign."<ref name=":4" />
In July 2018, Dobbs defended the Trump administration's decision to ban a CNN reporter from a press event.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/media/398919-lou-dobbs-to-cnn-after-white-house-bans-cnn-reporter-who-the-hell-are-you|title=Lou Dobbs to CNN after White House bans reporter: 'Who the hell are you?'|last=Birnbaum|first=Emily|date=2018-07-25|work=TheHill|access-date=2018-07-26|language=en}}</ref> Multiple Fox colleagues, including Fox News President Jay Wallace, had shown solidarity with CNN and called on the White House to rescind the ban.<ref name=":7" /> In 2012, when a ''Daily Caller'' reporter was criticized by the White House for shouting out a question during an address by Obama, Dobbs defended the reporter, saying "What is rude is a president not speaking to the American people and taking the questions of the White House press."<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/jake-tapper-calls-out-foxs-lou-dobbs-for-attacking-cnns-kaitlan-collins|title=Jake Tapper Calls Out Fox’s Lou Dobbs on ‘Colbert’ for Attacking CNN’s Kaitlan Collins|last=Wilstein|first=Matt|date=2018-07-27|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-07-27|language=en}}</ref> ''CNN''<nowiki/>'s [[Jake Tapper]] suggested that Dobbs was hypocritical, saying "Lou Dobbs, it might surprise you to find out, had a very different take on the situation.... Sometimes I find some people in this environment, you will be interested to know, say the exact opposite thing about President Trump than they did about President Obama."<ref name=":8" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.salon.com/2018/07/26/fox-news-tries-to-stand-in-solidarity-with-cnn-against-white-house-but-not-everyone-is-on-board/|title=Fox News tries to "stand in strong solidarity with CNN" — but not everyone is on board|date=2018-07-26|work=Salon|access-date=2018-07-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
In August 2018, Dobbs called CNN journalist [[Jim Acosta]] "delicate" and "triggered" after Acosta recorded a hostile crowd Trump supporters at a rally harassing him.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/jim-acosta-calls-sean-hannity-a-propagandist-for-profit-2018-8?utm_source=reddit.com&r=US&IR=T|title='A propagandist for profit, peddling lies every night': CNN correspondent Jim Acosta goes in on Fox News host Sean Hannity|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/video/2018/08/01/lou-dobbs-criticizes-jim-acosta-triggered-and-delicate-after-trump-supporters-harassed-him-rally/220883|title=Lou Dobbs criticizes Jim Acosta as "triggered" and "delicate" after Trump supporters harassed him at rally|date=2018-08-01|work=Media Matters for America|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en}}</ref>
That same month, Dobbs ran a segment pushing unsubstantiated claims that Google was biased against Trump and that Google was promoting anti-Trump stories.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://www.axios.com/trump-tweet-google-censorship-e5fb9792-069b-419e-8506-03855d3bf9c7.html|title=Go deeper: Tracing Trump's Google censorship tweet|website=Axios|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2018/08/28/a-short-investigation-into-trumps-tweets-on-rigged-google-results-about-himself/|title=Analysis {{!}} A short investigation into Trump’s claims of ‘RIGGED’ Google results against him|last=|first=|date=|website=Washington Post|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref> Following Dobbs' segment, Trump tweeted that Google was suppressing conservatives and he tasked economic adviser Larry Kudlow to look into regulating Google.<ref name=":9" />
In September 2018, after Trump falsely claimed that the official death count from [[Hurricane Maria death toll controversy|Hurricane Maria]] in Puerto Rico were fabricated by Democrats, Dobbs defended Trump's assertion.<ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/406644-trump-shares-lou-dobbs-segment-doubling-down-on-his-puerto-rico|title=Trump shares Lou Dobbs segment praising his Puerto Rico claims|last=Keller|first=Megan|date=2018-09-13|work=TheHill|access-date=2018-09-14|language=en}}</ref> Dobbs claimed that "the numbers were inflated" and that the organizations behind the numbers "threw out science, statistics, and evidence to discredit the Trump administration."<ref name=":10" />
In October 2018, when CNN and a number of prominent Democrats were targeted with bomb attempts, Dobbs described the bomb attempts as "fake news" and promoted conspiracy theories that the bomb attempts were by Democrats who sought to increase their support in the upcoming mid-term elections.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/lou-dobbs-tweet-conspiracy-theory-democrats-mail-bombs-2018-10?r=UK&IR=T|title=Lou Dobbs promotes conspiracy theory that Democrats sent explosive devices to Clinton, Obama, and Soros to improve midterm chances|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/media/413103-fox-business-networks-dobbs-calls-bomb-attacks-fake-bombs-in-since-deleted|title=Fox Business Network's Dobbs calls bomb attacks 'fake bombs' in since-deleted tweet|last=Nam|first=Rafael|date=2018-10-25|work=TheHill|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}}</ref> Several Fox News employees expressed dismay over Dobbs' rhetoric, with one employee telling CNN, "It's people like Dobbs who really ruin it for all the hard working journalists at Fox."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/10/25/media/lou-dobbs-fake-bombs/index.html|title=Fox Business Network host Lou Dobbs peddles conspiracy theory about suspicious packages|last=Business|first=Oliver Darcy, CNN|work=CNN|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref>
When the Trump administration rescinded CNN White House correspondent Jim Acosta's press pass, Dobbs supported the administration. At the same time, numerous media organizations, including Fox News, spoke out against the Trump administration's decision. When U.S. District Court Judge Timothy Kelly, a Trump appointee, temporarily restored Acosta's press pass, Dobbs described the ruling as "absurd."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/lou-dobbs-loses-his-mind-after-cnn-defeats-white-house-over-acostas-press-access|title=Lou Dobbs Loses His Mind After CNN Defeats White House Over Acosta’s Press Access|last=Melendez|first=Pilar|date=2018-11-16|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}}</ref> When the Trump administration complied with the ruling, Dobbs called on the administration to ignore the ruling and tell the "district court judge to go to hell."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/lou-dobbs-freaks-after-trump-surrenders-to-cnns-jim-acosta-says-president-should-tell-judge-to-go-to-hell|title=Lou Dobbs: Trump Should Tell Judge in CNN Case to ‘Go to Hell’|last=Wilstein|first=Matt|date=2018-11-20|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thewrap.com/lou-dobbs-suggests-trump-should-have-ignored-court-order-on-jim-acosta/|title=Lou Dobbs Suggests Trump Should Have Ignored Court Order on Acosta|date=2018-11-20|work=TheWrap|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
===George Soros=== Dobbs has peddled numerous conspiracy theories about the Jewish-American philanthropist and businessman George Soros.<ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/10/28/media/lou-dobbs-fox-news-guest/index.html|title=Fox condemns rhetoric used by Lou Dobbs guest as channel's star host faces growing criticism|last=Business|first=Oliver Darcy, CNN|work=CNN|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> Dobbs has referred to him as an "evil SOB" and insidious.<ref name=":11" />
Dobbs's Fox Business Channel shows stirred controversy in October 2018 when a guest on Dobbs' show used what many described as an anti-Semitic trope to suggest that the State Department was "Soros-occupied" territory (which echoed the anti-Semitic trope of a "Zionist-occupied government").<ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newrepublic.com/minutes/151926/lou-dobbs-extreme-even-fox-business-news|title=Lou Dobbs is too extreme even for Fox Business News.|work=The New Republic|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> The remarks came days after bombing attempts on Soros, and the remarks were replayed on Fox Business hours after an anti-Semitic attack on a Pittsburgh synagogue which killed 11 people.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/media/413542-fox-business-exec-condemns-rhetoric-of-guest-who-blamed-migrant-caravan-on|title=Fox Business drops guest who blamed migrant caravan on 'Soros-occupied State Department'|last=Anapol|first=Avery|date=2018-10-28|work=TheHill|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en}}</ref> After widespread condemnation, Fox stated that the guest, Chris Farrell of Judicial Watch, would no longer be booked.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/money/nation-now/2018/10/29/lou-dobbs-controversy-fox-bans-george-soros-conspiracy-theory-guest/1804634002/|title=Fox bans Lou Dobbs' guest over George Soros conspiracy theory|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":11" />
===Other views=== Dobbs was a registered [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]. Though he made a donation of $1,000 to the [[George W. Bush presidential campaign, 2000|Bush-Cheney]] campaign in January 2001,<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.newsmeat.com/media_political_donations/Lou_Dobbs.php | title = Lou Dobbs's Federal Campaign Contribution Report | date = 2007-02-04 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061104180416/http://www.newsmeat.com/media_political_donations/Lou_Dobbs.php | archivedate = 2006-11-04 | df = }}</ref> he often has described the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]] and the then Republican-controlled [[United States Congress|Congress]] as "disgraceful." He has also argued that both parties are controlled by corporate interests.<ref>Dobbs, Lou, (2006). War on the Middle Class. The Dobbs Group, pp. 127-128</ref>
Dobbs is [[pro-choice]], opposes [[gun control]] and, though he is a fiscal conservative, supports some government regulations, as revealed in a ''[[60 Minutes]]'' interview.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/05/03/60minutes/main2758082_page3.shtml |title=Lou Dobbs, "Advocacy" Journalist? |publisher=Cbsnews.com |date=2007-05-06 |accessdate=2010-04-12}}</ref> He has been critical of trade policies that he says encourage "sending jobs overseas".<ref>{{Cite news| url = http://msnbc.msn.com/id/4670239/ | title = CNN's Lou Dobbs is a man on a mission | work = [[MSNBC]] | accessdate = 2007-06-03 | agency = Associated Press | date = 2004-04-09 }}</ref>
Dobbs' stance on trade has earned plaudits from some [[Labor unions in the United States|trade union]] activists on the traditional [[Modern liberalism in the United States|political left]], while his stance on immigration tends to appeal to the [[American conservatism|right]].<ref name="Madashell"/> In an interview with [[Larry King]], Dobbs revealed that he is now "an unaffiliated independent" owing to dissatisfaction with both the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic parties]].
In June 2006, as the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] debated the [[Federal Marriage Amendment]], Dobbs was critical of the action. He asserted that marriage was threatened more by financial crises perpetuated by Bush administration economic policy than by [[same-sex marriage]].<ref>{{Cite news| url = http://www.cnn.com/2006/US/06/06/dobbs.june7/index.html | title = Dobbs: Gay marriage amendment sheer nonsense | date = 2006-06-08 | accessdate = 2006-01-17 | work=CNN}}</ref>
Dobbs is the author of ''War on the Middle Class'', in which he claims that both Democrats and Republicans are harming the middle class. In it, he comes out strongly against the [[Bush tax cuts]], which he argues favor the wealthy, and argued for raising the U.S. [[minimum wage]] from what was then $5.15 an hour.<ref>{{Cite news| url = http://www.cnn.com/2006/US/10/10/Dobbs.Oct11/index.html | title = Dobbs: Middle class needs to fight back now | date = 2006-10-18 | accessdate = 2006-01-17 | work=CNN}}</ref>
== Reception == Dobbs has also been criticized for his lack of [[journalistic ethics]] by liberal news journalist [[Amy Goodman]]. She accused him of flagrant errors in his reporting and his staff's association with disreputable sources, stating that "he has a special responsibility to rely on facts and to correct misstatements of fact."<ref name="amy06seattlePI">{{Cite news|title=CNN's Lou Dobbs needs to follow his own advice |date=December 5, 2007 |first=AMY |last=GOODMAN| url=http://www.seattlepi.com/opinion/342375_amy06.html|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]}}</ref>
==Awards== Dobbs has won numerous major awards for his television journalism, most notably a [[Emmy Award|Lifetime Achievement Emmy Award]] and a [[Cable ACE Awards|Cable Ace Award]]. He received the [[Peabody Award|George Foster Peabody Award]] for his coverage of the [[Black Monday (1987)|1987 stock market crash]]. He also has received the Luminary Award of the Business Journalism Review in 1990, the [[Horatio Alger, Jr.|Horatio Alger]] Association Award for Distinguished Americans in 1999 and the National Space Club Media Award in 2000. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' has named Dobbs "TV's Premier Business News Anchorman". In 2004, Dobbs was awarded the Eugene Katz Award For Excellence in the Coverage of Immigration by the [[Center for Immigration Studies]]<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.cis.org/articles/Katz/katz2004.html | title = 2004 Eugene Katz Award For Excellence in the Coverage of Immigration |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040803231123/http://www.cis.org/articles/Katz/katz2004.html| archivedate =August 3, 2004 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> and in 2005 he received the [[Alexis de Tocqueville Institution|Alexis de Tocqueville Institution's]] Statesmanship Award.<ref>{{cite web| url = https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2005/03/07/323990/73929/en/Reporter-Analyst-Dobbs-is-AdTI-Statesman-Brown.html | title = Reporter, analyst Dobbs is AdTI Statesman | accessdate = 2007-01-16 }}</ref> Dobbs was named "Father of the Year" by the National Father's Day Committee in 1993.<ref>{{Cite news| url = http://www.cnn.com/CNN/anchors_reporters/dobbs.lou.html | work = [[CNN]] | accessdate = 2007-06-03 | title = Lou Dobbs |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070519014136/http://www.cnn.com/CNN/anchors_reporters/dobbs.lou.html |archivedate = May 19, 2007}}</ref> In 2008 Dobbs received the American Legion Public Relations Award from the National Commander of The [[American Legion]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Lou Dobbs: PR Award Recipient, 2008|url=https://www.legion.org/prawards/2008/lou-dobbs|publisher=[[American Legion]]|accessdate=March 31, 2017}}</ref>
==Books== * Lou Dobbs, with James O. Born, ''Border War'', Forge, (2014). {{ISBN|9780765327710}}. * Lou Dobbs, ''Independents Day: Awakening The American Spirit'', Viking, (2007). {{ISBN|978-0-670-01836-9}}. * Lou Dobbs, ''Exporting America: Why Corporate Greed Is Shipping American Jobs Overseas'', Warner Books, (2004). {{ISBN|0-446-57744-8}}. * Lou Dobbs, ''Space: The Next Business Frontier'' with [[HP Newquist]], Pocket Books, (2001). {{ISBN|0-7434-2389-5}} * Lou Dobbs, ''War on the Middle Class: How the Government, Big Business, and Special Interest Groups Are Waging War on the American Dream and How to Fight Back'', Viking, (2006). {{ISBN|0-670-03792-3}}. * Ron Hira and Anil Hira, with foreword by Lou Dobbs, ''Outsourcing America: What's behind Our National Crisis and how we can reclaim American Jobs.'' (AMACOM), American Management Association, (May 2005). {{ISBN|0-8144-0868-0}}. * Lou Dobbs, "Upheaval", Threshold Editions, (2014) {{ISBN|978-1-4767-2885-8}}
==See also== * [[North American monetary union]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.foxbusiness.com/on-air/lou-dobbs-tonight/index.html Lou Dobbs Tonight website] * {{IMDb name|id=1463161|name=Lou Dobbs}} * {{C-SPAN|loudobbs}}
{{CNN Anchors}} {{CNN International personalities}} {{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{onesource|date=April 2017}} {{dablink|This article is about the American businessman. For the British businessman , see [[Richard Baker (UK businessman)]].}} {{Other people|Richard Baker}}
'''Richard "Dick" Baker''' (September 3, 1946 – April 14, 2009) was an [[United States|American]] businessman and [[surfing|surf]] apparel executive for [[Ocean Pacific]]. Baker helped to shape the surf apparel industry as president and chief executive of Ocean Pacific, also known as OP.<ref name=lat>{{cite news |first=Adam|last=Tschorn|title=Richard Baker dies at 62; former Ocean Pacific president bridged surf industry and Wall Street|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-dick-baker16-2009apr16,0,648591.story|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=|date=2009-04-16|accessdate=2009-05-10}}</ref>
==Biography==
===Early life=== Baker was born on September 3, 1946 in Los Angeles.<ref name=lat/> He grew up in the [[San Fernando Valley]] and earned his bachelor's degree from [[California State University, Northridge]].<ref name=lat/>
===Career=== Baker first entered the apparel industry as a college student. He became a [[buyer]] at a men's specialty store to pay for school.<ref name=lat/> He later became a buyer for the now defunct [[Bullock's]] [[department store]].<ref name=lat/>
Baker became head of the [[Marithé François Girbaud]]'s U.S. division, based in [[New York City]], in 1980.<ref name=lat/> He gradually moved on to head other clothing brands. In 1983, Baker became the president and [[chief executive]] of [[Izod|Izod Ltd]].'s [[Fashion|menswear]] division.<ref name=lat/> He became president of [[Esprit Sport]] in 1986 before later moving on to become the head of [[Tommy Hilfiger]]'s women's clothing division.<ref name=lat/>
===Ocean Pacific=== In 1998, Baker and his partners at the Doyle & Boissiere investment group, which is based in [[Burlingame, California]], acquired the [[Ocean Pacific]] heritage surf [[brand]].<ref name=lat/> Ocean Pacific was in financial trouble at the time as [[consumer preference]]s had changed over the years.
Baker became the chief executive of Ocean Pacific following the 1998 acquisition.<ref name=lat/> He was able to successfully revive the flagging label. Under his helm, Baker led Ocean Pacific through two sales. The first was to [[Warnaco Group]] in 2004, which acquired Ocean Pacific for $40 million.<ref name=lat/> The second sale, in 2006, was to [[Iconix Brand Group]], a [[surf wear]] maker, for an estimated $54 million.<ref name=lat/>
Baker remained the president of Ocean Pacific until he stepped down in 2006, and continued as a [[consultant]] with the company until 2007.<ref name=lat/>
===Surf Industry Manufacturers Association=== Baker joined the board of directors of the [[Surf Industry Manufacturers Association]] ([[SIMA]]), based in [[Aliso Viejo, California]], in 2000 while he was the chief executive of Ocean Pacific.<ref name=lat/> He served as the head of SIMA for nine years before becoming the chairman [[emeritus]] of the organization.<ref name=lat/> The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' noted that as head of SIMA, Baker directed the business of "selling [[Surfing|surf]] to the suits" in the larger business community.<ref name=lat/> He also served as a mentor to the CEOs and heads of other surf oriented apparel brands. [[Fernando Aguerre]], the co-founder of [[Reef (company)|Reef]] clothing company and current chief executive of [[Liquid Tribe]], later called Baker, "part father, part brother and part friend."<ref name=lat/>
In a speech to a surf insutry gathering in [[San José del Cabo]], [[Mexico]], in May 2005, Baker told attendees that, "Surf is on the [[world stage]], and this hard-core, laid-back industry has been discovered by the suits. The non- endemic business types see this as an area of growth, and if you see this as a threat, then get a life -- it's a compliment."<ref name=lat/>
Baker also told the surf industry to use their influence to do good works saying in 2006, "Pick your spot and make a difference...Whether you're big or small, give back what you can."<ref name=lat/>
===Death=== Richard Baker died on April 14, 2009, at [[Mission Hospital]] in [[Mission Viejo, California]], after a two-year battle with cancer.<ref name=lat/> He was 62 years old and was survived by his wife of 19 years, Una Baker; sons, Ryan and Jack; his father, Donald Baker, and his sister, Donna Smith Vigil.<ref name=lat/>
The Surf Industry Manufacturers Association announced that its plans to honor Baker with its Lifetime Achievement Award at its 20th annual [[Waterman's Ball]] in August 2009.<ref name=lat/>
[[Richard Woolcott]], the founder and CEO of [[Volcom]] told the ''LA Times'', "Dick was a great friend, [[mentor]] and [[role model]] to many of us in the industry. He understood the magic of [[action sports]] and helped us harness it into big-picture thinking and execution. But most of all, he was a wonderful human being with a loving heart and spirit. He was always supportive in what we were doing, lending his advice and positive feedback. He was a blessing to this industry and will be deeply missed."<ref name=lat/>
Fernando Aguerre, founder of Reef, said in reaction to Baker's death, "And I feel like an orphan today."<ref name=lat/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Baker, Richard}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:American retail chief executives]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:California State University, Northridge alumni]]
